sentences.english: Today's teachers are not the ranging extremists of TORY and tabloid mythology.
sentences.chinese: 今天的老師不屬於託利時代的極端分子和小報的神話。

sentences.english: During this decade newspapers changed to the four-column, tabloid style paper in 1900.
sentences.chinese: 1900年，報紙變成了四欄的小報形式。

sentences.english: Don't be a rat fink, Jack.
sentences.chinese: 不要可惡地打小報告，傑克。

sentences.english: He believes that the tabloid press has behaved disgracefully.
sentences.chinese: 他認爲小報媒體的行爲不太光彩。

sentences.english: Tabloid gossip derives its entertainment value from subtle suggestions.
sentences.chinese: 八卦小報費盡心思，企圖從細枝末節中發現文娛價值。

sentences.english: The Swiss tabloid Blick made it look like it was blood pouring from the temple.
sentences.chinese: 瑞士小報布利克使它看起來是血從寺廟中噴湧而出。

sentences.english: Discourage gossip, and don't put people in the position of spying or reporting on each other.
sentences.chinese: 制止流言蜚語，不要讓人做臥底或者打小報告。

sentences.english: Queen was a regular tabloid presence and a fixture at the Starling City club scene.
sentences.chinese: 奎恩曾是八卦小報紅人，也是斯特林市夜店的熟客。

sentences.english: 's now-closed News of the World tabloid.
sentences.chinese: 《世界新聞報》是新聞集團旗下小報，現已停刊。

sentences.english: This was, as one of our tabloid newspapers had it, the "Peking Ruck".
sentences.chinese: 我們的小報把他們叫做“北京羣歐隊”。

sentences.english: Daughter: A tattletale? Did you just call me a tattletale?
sentences.chinese: 你說我是打小報告的嗎？

sentences.english: The tabloids know this and satisfy this obsession.
sentences.chinese: 街頭小報都深諳此道，藉機滿足了這種慾望。

sentences.english: These big-eyed scrawny boys put out a small newspaper .
sentences.chinese: 這些大眼睛的瘦骨嶙峋的孩子辦了一份小報。

sentences.english: Those who squeal on colleagues in returnforfavorsare the most hated intheoffice.
sentences.chinese: 辦公室裏最可恨的就是那些打小報告的人。

sentences.english: Royal gossip is a staple of the tabloid press.
sentences.chinese: 圍繞王室成員的蜚短流長是小報的主要內容。

sentences.english: I told my teacher on Dolly for stealing my book.
sentences.chinese: 我跟老師打小報告說多莉偷我的書。

definition: frightening words to scare people (idiom); alarmist talk/reds under the beds
to invent crazy nonsense/to cook up (excuses)/to talk at random/wild babble
to shoot without aim (idiom); fig. to speak without thinking/firing blindly/to shoot in the air/a shot in the dark
to churn out large quantities without regard for quality (idiom); rough and slipshod work
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to talk about this and that (idiom); to ramble incoherently
